Award.AwardTitle: CSR: EAGER: Exploratory Research on Data Quality-Centric Cloud Infrastructure for Federated Sensor Services

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EAGER project supports foundational research toward the exploration of data quality (DQ) issues in the context of sensor networks. Speciﬁcally, this project will include three major research thrusts: (1) a multidimensional DQ model for sensor feeds that can accommodate a
diverse set of DQ attributes. The project will carry out a comprehensive study into various DQ dimensions which will include inventing metrics and mechanisms for accurately quantifying the DQ dimensions; (2) The project will create a service oriented architectural framework for federated sensor service clouds in which DQ awareness is pervasive at all levels and all aspects of the architecture. Our core idea is to virtualize all sensors and auxiliary services in a DQ-aware manner; and (3) The project will devise DQ-aware autonomic techniques for sensor service discovery, feed composition and adaptation towards environmental dynamics. Our techniques will enhance scalability by detecting feed processing tasks that are shared among multiple user requests, as well as by cloud topology-aware distribution of feed processing tasks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Internet of Things (IoT) is revolutionizing a number of important domains such as meteorology, emergency services, logistics, transportation and science by enabling scientists, policy makers, public infrastructure/natural resource managers, and businesses to access remotely sensed data over the Internet in real-time. It is widely expected that the next few years will witness ‘servitization’ of domain sensing functionalities wherein high-quality feeds from a variety of sensors will be shared and traded on a cloud-based platform. Such an ecosystem will necessarily have multiple stakeholders including sensor data providers, data consumers, infrastructure providers and data analytics service providers.

In this project, we performed foundational research toward designing a cloud-based, data quality (DQ)-centric framework for sharing, discovering and composing remote sensor feeds. One of the major themes of this project is that the notion of data quality (DQ) is fundamentally important for sensor applications, and DQ needs to be a first class design parameter. This project systematically explored the issues and challenges involved in building DQ-centric cloud infrastructure to effectively support a sensor services ecosystem. In this context, this project resulted in the following five major outcomes.

First, a multidimensional DQ model has been developed for sensor feeds. In this conceptual model, various DQ attributes form distinct dimensions. This multidimensional DQ model forms the foundation upon which the architecture and various algorithms and techniques of the cloud-based sensor services framework are based. Several quality attributes that are important for sensor feeds such as accuracy, error rate, frequency, error rate, availability, timeliness, validity and trustworthiness have been identified and studied.

Second, A DQ-centric architecture has been designed for cloud-based sensor services platform. A unique aspect of this architecture is the DQ-aware virtualization of sensor feeds. In other words, the feed from each sensor is logically represented within the architecture, and this representation includes not only the content descriptors but also the data quality descriptors. A markup language called SDQ-ML has been designed for annotating sensor feeds.

Third, we have designed algorithms and techniques for quality-aware sensor feed discovery, processing and adaptation. The sensor feed discovery algorithm enables sensor applications to find appropriate sensor feeds taking into account both the content and the DQ attributes. The adaptation techniques handle various environmental dynamics such as sudden fluctuations in DQ and sensor failures while shielding the end-applications from major disruptions.

Fourth, our experimental study on the relationship between data quality and energy efficiency has shown that the frequency of the sensor feed has the biggest impact on energy consumption. We have also shown that significant energy savings can be obtained by batching transmissions from sensor feeds to the cloud.

Fifth, this project has also provided training and educational opportunities for many students at the University of Georgia. It has provided dissertation topics to two PhD and two masters students. Another PhD student's thesis is closely related to this project. Furthermore topics related to this project were taught in two courses at the University of Georgia. Students were provided the opportunity to work on course projects related to this project. This provided students hands-on experience with cutting edge technologies such as the cloud and the Internet of Things. 

In summary, this project resulted in models, algorithms and techniques that can significantly reduce the overheads involved in sharing, discovering and processing remote sensor feeds in various application domains.
